TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit Point4D extends System.ValueType implements class System.IFormattable

Docs.summary: Represents an x-, y-, z-, and w-coordinate point in world space used in performing transformations with non-affine [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_3d](../../add/includes/tlasharptla-3d-md.md)] matrices.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In XAML, the delimiter between the values of a Point4D can be either a comma or a space. Some cultures might use the comma character as the decimal delimiter instead of the period character. XAML processing for invariant culture defaults to en-US in most XAML processor implementations, and expects the period to be the decimal delimiter. You should avoid using the comma character as the decimal delimiter if specifying a Point4D in XAML, because that will clash with the string type conversion of a Point4D attribute value into its components. ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` -or- ``` ## XAML Values *x* The component of this Point4D structure. *y* The component of this Point4D structure. *z* The component of this Point4D structure. *w* The component of this Point4D structure.

MemberSignature.Value: public Point4D (double x, double y, double z, double w);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(float64 x, float64 y, float64 z, float64 w) cil managed

Docs.param: The x-coordinate of the new <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D"> structure.
The y-coordinate of the new <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D"> structure.
The z-coordinate of the new <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D"> structure.
The w-coordinate of the new <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D"> structure.

Docs.summary: Determines whether the specified <see cref="T:System.Object"> is a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure and if the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A> properties of the specified <see cref="T:System.Object"> are equal to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A> properties of this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
Docs.returns:
`true` if instances are equal; otherwise, `false`.
`true` if (the passed <see cref="T:System.Object">) is a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure and is identical with this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure; `false` otherwise.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If (the passed object) is not a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure, this method returns `false`.
Because a <xref:System.Double> value can lose precision when arithmetic operations are performed on them, a comparison between two <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> values that are logically equal might fail.
## Examples The following example shows how to check whether an <xref:System.Object> and a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure are equal.

Docs.returns: `true` if the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A> components of and are equal; `false` otherwise.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Two <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structures are equal if the values of their <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A> properties are the same.
Because <xref:System.Double> values can lose precision when arithmetic operations are performed on them, a comparison between two <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> instances that are logically equal might fail.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Offset (double deltaX, double deltaY, double deltaZ, double deltaW);
.method public hidebysig instance void Offset(float64 deltaX, float64 deltaY, float64 deltaZ, float64 deltaW) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount to offset the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A> coordinate of this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
The amount to offset the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A> coordinate of this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
The amount to offset the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A> coordinate of this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
The amount to offset the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A> coordinate of this <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
Docs.summary: Translates the <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D"> structure by the specified amounts.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Note that calling the Offset method will only have an effect if you can change the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A> properties directly. Because <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> is a value type, if you reference a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> object by using a property or indexer, you get a copy of the object, not a reference to the object. If you attempt to change <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.W%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Y%2A>, or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D.Z%2A> on a property or indexer reference, a compiler error occurs. Similarly, calling Offset on the property or indexer will not change the underlying object. If you want to change the value of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> that is referenced as a property or indexer, create a new <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D>, modify its fields, and then assign the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> back to the property or indexer.
## Examples The following example shows how to offset a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point4D> structure.
[!code-cs[point4dsample#Mil4DPoints3DN7](../../add/codesnippet/CSharp/Mil4dPoints/Window1.xaml.cs#mil4dpoints3dn7)] [!code-vb[point4dsample#Mil4DPoints3DN7](../../add/codesnippet/VisualBasic/mil4dpoints/window1.xaml.vb#mil4dpoints3dn7)]
